message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modeling Public Mood and Emotion: Twitter Sentiment and Socio-Economic Phenomena
Paper Abstract: We perform a sentiment analysis of all tweets published on the microblogging platform Twitter in the second half of 2008. We use a psychometric instrument to extract six mood states (tension, depression, anger, vigor, fatigue, confusion) from the aggregated Twitter content and compute a six-dimensional mood vector for each day in the timeline. We compare our results to a record of popular events gathered from media and sources. We find that events in the social, political, cultural and economic sphere do have a significant, immediate and highly specific effect on the various dimensions of public mood. We speculate that large scale analyses of mood can provide a solid platform to model collective emotive trends in terms of their predictive value with regards to existing social as well as economic indicators.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "sentiment analysis". Here's a summary of the results:

## Overview

Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining or emotion AI) is the use of natural language processing, text analysis, computational linguistics, and biometrics to systematically identify, extract, quantify, and study affective states and subjective information.

## Applications

Sentiment analysis is widely applied to voice of the customer materials such as reviews and survey responses, online and social media, and healthcare materials for applications that range from marketing to customer service to clinical medicine.

## Basic Tasks

A basic task in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given text at the document, sentence, or feature/aspect level—whether the expressed opinion in a document, a sentence or an entity feature/aspect is positive, negative, or neutral.

## Advanced Forms

The search results also revealed advanced variations, including multimodal sentiment analysis, which is a technology for traditional text-based sentiment analysis that includes modalities such as audio and visual data.

The search results include information about sentiment analysis companies, applications in financial markets, and various technical implementations of the technology.

I've completed the web search for "sentiment analysis". Here's a summary of the results:

## Overview

Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining or emotion AI) is the use of natural language processing, text analysis, computational linguistics, and biometrics to systematically identify, extract, quantify, and study affective states and subjective information.

## Applications

Sentiment analysis is widely applied to voice of the customer materials such as reviews and survey responses, online and social media, and healthcare materials for applications that range from marketing to customer service to clinical medicine.

## Basic Tasks

A basic task in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given text at the document, sentence, or feature/aspect level—whether the expressed opinion in a document, a sentence or an entity feature/aspect is positive, negative, or neutral.

## Advanced Forms

The search results also revealed advanced variations, including multimodal sentiment analysis, which is a technology for traditional text-based sentiment analysis that includes modalities such as audio and visual data.

The search results include information about sentiment analysis companies, applications in financial markets, and various technical implementations of the technology.

I've successfully performed a web search for "natural language processing text analysis". Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Natural Language Processing and Text Analysis

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Key NLP Techniques

The search results highlight several important NLP techniques:
- Lemmatization is the process of reducing inflected words to a base form
- Sentence breaking involves finding sentence boundaries in text
- Word-sense disambiguation—the differentiation of meaning of words—is identified as a main problem of language understanding

## Tools and Resources

Several specialized tools are used in NLP and text analysis:
- Gensim is an open-source library for unsupervised topic modeling, document indexing, retrieval by similarity, and other natural language processing functionalities
- GATE (General Architecture for Text Engineering) is a Java suite of natural language processing tools for many tasks, including information extraction in many languages

The search results show that NLP and text analysis are well-established fields with diverse applications in research, industry, and education.

Based on the search results, here's information about Twitter as a social media platform:

## Overview

Twitter is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.(no content)Twitter, Inc. was an American social media company based in San Francisco, California, which operated and was named for its flagship social media network prior to its rebrand as X.

## Platform Features

Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts (commonly and unofficially known as "tweets") and like other users' content.(no content)The platform also includes direct messaging, video and other features.

## Growth and User Base

By the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users.(no content)Twitter then experienced considerable growth during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

## Recent Changes

Twitter, Inc. was merged with X Corp. in April 2023.(no content)Twitter was an American social networking service that was rebranded as X in 2023.

## Uses

The platform has been used for various purposes, including political communication, business marketing, customer service, and as a tool for spreading information on diverse topics.

Web search results for query: "psychometrics psychology measurement"

Links: [{"title":"Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics"},{"title":"Psychometric software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometric_software"},{"title":"Psychological statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_statistics"},{"title":"Computational psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_psychometrics"},{"title":"Measuring the Mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measuring_the_Mind"},{"title":"Item analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Item_analysis"},{"title":"Quantitative psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_psychology"},{"title":"Psychometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometry"},{"title":"Psychometric function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometric_function"},{"title":"Category:Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Psychometrics"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of psychometrics in psychology measurement:

## What is Psychometrics?

Psychometrics is a field of study within psychology concerned with the theory and technique of measurement, generally covering specialized fields within psychology and education devoted to testing, measurement, assessment, and related activities.

## Core Focus

Psychometrics is concerned with the objective measurement of latent constructs that cannot be directly observed, with examples including intelligence, personality factors (e.g., introversion), mental disorders, and educational achievement.(no content)The levels of individuals on nonobservable latent variables are inferred through mathematical modeling based on what is observed from individuals' responses to items on tests and scales.

## Key Measurement Approaches

Psychometrics deals with measurement of psychological attributes and involves developing and applying statistical models for mental measurements, with the measurement theories divided into two major areas: Classical test theory and Item Response Theory.

## Practical Applications

Some psychometric researchers focus on the construction and validation of assessment instruments, including surveys, scales, and questionnaires, while others focus on research relating to measurement theory (e.g., item response theory, intraclass correlation) or specialize as learning and development professionals.

## Professional Field

Practitioners are described as psychometricians, although not all who engage in psychometric research go by this title, with most psychometricians being psychologists with advanced graduate training in psychometrics and measurement theory.

Links: [{"title":"Mood (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_(psychology)"},{"title":"Emotion classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_classification"},{"title":"Emotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion"},{"title":"Affect (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_(psychology)"},{"title":"Affect measures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_measures"},{"title":"Affective science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_science"},{"title":"Affective neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_neuroscience"},{"title":"Dispositional affect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispositional_affect"},{"title":"Emotionality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotionality"},{"title":"Emotional lability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_lability"}]

I've completed the web search for "emotion psychology mood". Here are the key findings:

## Key Distinctions

In psychology, a mood is an affective state that, in contrast to emotions or feelings, is less specific, less intense and less likely to be provoked by a particular stimulus or event.(no content)An emotion tends to have a clear focus (i.e., its cause is self-evident), while mood tends to be more unfocused and diffuse.

## Duration and Intensity

Mood is generally viewed as more persistent and less intense than emotional state, and as a result more stable.(no content)Moods can last for hours, days, weeks, or longer.

## Valence

Moods are typically described as having either a positive or negative valence.(no content)Negative moods can manipulate how individuals interpret and translate the world around them, and can also affect an individual's judgment and perception of objects and events.

## Affect, Emotions, and Mood

Affect, in psychology, is the underlying experience of feeling, emotion, attachment, or mood, and encompasses a wide range of emotional states that can be positive (e.g., happiness, joy, excitement) or negative (e.g., sadness, anger, fear, disgust).(no content)Emotions are often intertwined with mood, temperament, personality, disposition, or creativity.

## Research Areas

Affective science is the scientific study of emotion or affect, which includes the study of emotion elicitation, emotional experience and the recognition of emotions in others, as well as the nature of feeling, mood, emotionally driven behaviour, decision-making, attention and self-regulation, and the underlying physiology and neuroscience of the emotions.

I've completed the web search for "economic indicators." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Economic indicators include various indices, earnings reports, and economic summaries such as unemployment rate, housing starts, consumer price index (a measure for inflation), gross domestic product, retail sales, and changes in credit conditions.

## Types of Economic Indicators

Economic indicators are classified into three main categories:

1. **Leading Indicators**: Leading indicators usually change before the economy as a whole changes and are useful as short-term predictors of the economy.(no content)Leading indicators include the index of consumer expectations, building permits, and credit conditions.

2. **Lagging Indicators**: Lagging indicators usually change after the economy as a whole does, typically with a lag of a few quarters, such as the unemployment rate which tends to increase two or three quarters after an upturn.

3. **Coincident Indicators**: Coincident indicators change at approximately the same time as the whole economy and include Gross Domestic Product, industrial production, personal income and retail sales.

## Key Sources

The Bureau of Labor Statistics is the principal fact-finding agency for the U.S. government in labor economics, with other producers of economic indicators including the United States Census Bureau and Bureau of Economic Analysis.

Links: [{"title":"Social media analytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_analytics"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social data analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_data_analysis"},{"title":"Social media measurement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_measurement"},{"title":"Social media mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_mining"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social media intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_intelligence"},{"title":"Media monitoring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_monitoring"},{"title":"Social media reach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_reach"}]

I've completed a web search for "social media analysis." Here's an overview of the results:

## Key Findings:

**Definition and Purpose:**
Social media analytics or social media monitoring is the process of gathering and analyzing data from social networks such as Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, or Twitter.(no content)It is commonly used by marketers to track online conversations about products and companies.

**Main Components:**
There are three main steps in analyzing social media: data identification, data analysis, and information interpretation.(no content)Many different types of analysis can be performed with social media data, including analysis of posts, sentiment, sentiment drivers, geography, demographics, etc.

**Types of Analysis:**
Analysis could be performed as real-time, near real-time, ad hoc exploration and deep analysis. Real-time analysis in social media is an important tool when trying to understand the public's perception of a certain topic as it unfolding to allow for reaction or an immediate change in course.

**Business Applications:**
Monitoring social media allows researchers to find insights into a brand's overall visibility on social media, to measure the impact of campaigns, to identify opportunities for engagement, to assess competitor activity and share of voice, and to detect impending crises.

**Tools and Methods:**
Companies use social-media monitoring tools to monitor, track, and analyze conversations to aid in their marketing, sales and other programs.

Social media analytics or social media monitoring is the process of gathering and analyzing data from social networks such as Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, or Twitter.(no content)It is commonly used by marketers to track online conversations about products and companies.

**Main Components:**
There are three main steps in analyzing social media: data identification, data analysis, and information interpretation.(no content)Many different types of analysis can be performed with social media data, including analysis of posts, sentiment, sentiment drivers, geography, demographics, etc.

**Types of Analysis:**
Analysis could be performed as real-time, near real-time, ad hoc exploration and deep analysis. Real-time analysis in social media is an important tool when trying to understand the public's perception of a certain topic as it unfolding to allow for reaction or an immediate change in course.

**Business Applications:**
Monitoring social media allows researchers to find insights into a brand's overall visibility on social media, to measure the impact of campaigns, to identify opportunities for engagement, to assess competitor activity and share of voice, and to detect impending crises.

**Tools and Methods:**
Companies use social-media monitoring tools to monitor, track, and analyze conversations to aid in their marketing, sales and other programs.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis and extracted all the key entities and relationships from the paper. Here's a summary of what I've accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - This paper proposes novel methods for analyzing public mood through Twitter sentiment analysis and introduces the application of psychometric instruments to social media data.

**Key Triples Identified and Validated:**

1. **Sentiment analysis** (method, uses) - Core technique for extracting emotional content from tweets
2. **Twitter** (tool, uses) - Primary data source for the study
3. **Psychometrics** (method, uses) - Framework for measuring psychological mood dimensions
4. **Mood (psychology)** (concept, proposes) - Novel computational analysis of six mood dimensions
5. **Natural language processing** (method, uses) - Enables automated text analysis at scale
6. **Economic indicator** (concept, uses) - Examines mood-economy correlations
7. **Social media analytics** (method, proposes) - Novel approach to understanding collective emotions

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms:
- ✅ Correct paper type classification
- ✅ 7 validated triples
- ✅ Mix of entity types (4 methods, 1 tool, 2 concepts)
- ✅ All triples meet validation requirements (min 1 "uses", contribution has "proposes")

The `triples_output.json` file is now complete and validated.

Sources:
- [Sentiment analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentiment_analysis)
- [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter)
- [Psychometrics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics)
- [Mood (psychology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_(psychology))
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
- [Economic indicator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_indicator)
- [Social media analytics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_analytics)
